summary: The Treasury plans to sell $30 billion Tuesday in four-week bills.

headline: U.S. Investor Wilbur Ross Eyes Japan Opportunities
summary: U.S. investor Wilbur Ross said Japan offers some of the most attractive investment opportunities in the developed world despite the strong yen, partly because he sees many Japanese companies as undervalued.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: A man builds a tent for a wedding in Pakistan, people sit outside a flooded house in Thailand, an exiled Tibetan protests in India and more.

headline: DJIA Rises; Caterpillar Leads Way
summary: Stocks rose Monday, pushing the Nasdaq Composite into positive territory for the year and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to the cusp of it.

headline: Suu Kyi's Fight for Democracy
summary: Many Myanmar residents view pro-democracy icon Aung San Suu Kyi as the rightful leader of Myanmar after her political party, the National League for Democracy, won the general elections held in 1990. Take a look at major events in Ms. Suu Kyi's life.

headline: Zynga Eyeing November IPO
summary: Bankers for Zynga are aiming to launch the social-gaming company's IPO in November, on the heels of the expected completion of the IPO of discount deal provider Groupon.

headline: TI Profit Falls as Chip Demand Slumps
summary: Chip maker Texas Instruments said its third-quarter profit fell 30% as economic uncertainty caused a broad slump in demand hit across its major business segments.

headline: FAA Wants Tails Checked on Boeing 757s
summary: U.S. regulators want airlines to check for hazardous corrosion on movable tail parts on hundreds of Boeing 757 jets that could result in pilots losing control of aircraft.

headline: McGurn: And Baby Makes Seven Billion
summary: Human beings are minds, not mouths.

headline: Stephens: How Many Nukes Does China Have?
summary: Plumbing the secret Underground Great Wall.

headline: Photos of the Day: Oct. 24
summary: In today's pictures, Bangkok residents sit outside their flooded houses, a customer picks up Steve Jobs's biography in Shanghai, a civil rights icon is mourned in Alabama, and more.

headline: Iran Displays Divisions After Charge of U.S. Plot
summary: Iranian officials have delivered conflicting responses to U.S. allegations that Tehran plotted to assassinate Saudi Arabia's ambassador in Washington, in a new sign of a split among Iran's decision makers.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Oct. 25
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Oct. 25

headline: China Regulator Warns on Insurers
summary: China's insurance regulator warned of domestic insurers' worsening ability to make payments to policyholders, and said it will help insurers tap the Hong Kong offshore yuan market for funds.

headline: I'm No Freeloader, I've Paid All My Life
summary: Dave Remes's letter "Your Tomorrow Spent for Boomers Today" (Oct. 21) is correct in asserting that boomers are taking form future generations. But he ignores the fact that boomers have paid the generous Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid tab of retirees and the poor as long as boomers have been working

headline: Treasurys Edge Lower
summary: Treasury investors laid low as they await Wednesday's euro-zone plan from the sidelines, leaving prices a tad lower after a tight-ranged trading session.

headline: Plains All American Discloses Bid
summary: Plains All American Pipeline publicly unveiled details of its offer to buy SemGroup, a proposal valuing the company at $1 billion that was rejected.

headline: HealthSpring, Crescent Financial: Biggest Price Gainers (HS, CRFN)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Big Bang Shot Down
summary: Of course, he does run a small, independent broker and sees little chance of Big Bang's reforms being reversed. "But until they are," he says, "I think we will be condemned to suffer the sort of mistakes, malpractice and calamities which helped to cause the current financial crisis."

headline: Italy Faces More Pressure To Find Growth
summary: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi is scrambling to stitch together growth-boosting measures after Germany and France complained he isn't pushing ahead fast enough with an economic overhaul.

headline: Procter & Gamble, SPDR S&P 500: Money Flow Leaders (PG, SPY)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Oil Settles Above $90
summary: Crude futures rose to their highest level in nearly three months as a condition emerged in the market suggesting a supply squeeze in the near term.

headline: Consumers Going 'Sideways'
summary: Kimberly-Clark cut its revenue outlook and the high end of its earnings forecast as it continues to struggle with high costs for raw materials. CEO Tom Falk said it feels like consumers are going "sideways."

headline: Timberland Boosts Earnings at VF Corp.
summary: VF Corp., whose stable of brands includes Wrangler, North Face and Vans, said sales and earnings were both up more than 20%, helped in part by its acquisition of Timberland.

headline: Gold Adds to Gains
summary: Gold futures settled higher amid hopes of a comprehensive solution to Europe's debt crisis and robust demand for physical gold in Asia.

headline: Rice Futures Jump on Thai Flooding
summary: U.S. rice futures got a boost from expectations that flooding in Thailand would reduce global supplies of the grain.

headline: Holland's Masterpiece Helps Rangers Tie Series
summary: Rangers pitcher Derek Holland scattered two hits over eight-and-a-third shutout innings to lead Texas over St. Louis 4-0.

headline: Copper Ends at 1-Month High
summary: Copper futures surged 7.1% as investors who had bet against the metal rushed to reverse those positions after strong manufacturing data from top consumer China and hopes for a European debt deal.

headline: IBM Seeks Bigger Stake In Big-Data Analytics
summary: IBM has made a big bet on providing analysis of what are known as "big data," and this week the company seeks to build on its position.

headline: Turkey's Central Bank to Unveil Plans to Boost Lira
summary: Turkey's central bank said it will unveil this week a package to support the lira, marking the latest step in an increasingly aggressive effort to shore up the embattled currency.

headline: India Official: Public Share Sales Not Enough to Meet Disinvestment Aim
summary: A senior Indian official put into words what has been clear for the past several months: The federal government is not going to be able to achieve its target of raising 400 billion rupees ($8 billion) this fiscal year just by selling stakes in state-run companies to the public.

headline: China's Geely Has No Interest in Saab Auto
summary: Zhejiang Geely's chairman said the Swedish car maker is too financially troubled for Geely to acquire as an agreement by two other Chinese auto makers to rescue Saab Automobile was terminated.

headline: Suzlon to Sell Non-Critical Assets
summary: Suzlon Energy will look at selling some of its non-critical assets in the next few months to generate funds for leveraging its balance sheet, Kirti Vagadia, Suzlon's group corporate finance head, said.

headline: Tymoshenko Faces New Investigation in Ukraine
summary: Prosecutors announced a new criminal investigation into jailed former Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko following President Viktor Yanukovych's rejection of Western demands to release her.

headline: Edison Shareholder Rejects EDF Offer
summary: A key shareholder in Italian power group Edison SpA rejected an offer by French state-controlled power giant Electricite de France to buy it out of Edison, saying the proposal would have it selling its stake at a discount.

headline: China Jails Two for Leaking Data
summary: A Chinese court has jailed two former officials for leaking confidential economic data, a rare punishment that is part of an effort to close loopholes in how the country manages the release of market-moving information.

headline: Halliburton Probing Its Angola Dealings
summary: Halliburton is conducting an internal investigation of potential violations of U.S. anticorruption laws by some of its personnel in oil-rich Angola.

headline: ArcelorMittal, Peabody Get 59.85% in Macarthur Coal
summary: Coal miner Peabody Energy and steelmaker ArcelorMittal secured a 59.85% stake in Australian coking-coal miner macarthur Coal and as a result has made its takeover offer unconditional.

headline: Radian CEO Calls for Unity to Stabilize Housing Market
summary: Radian Group chief S.A. Ibrahim warned that lenders and insurers need to work closely with the U.S. government to prevent further housing-market "shocks" in the wake of the takeover of a rival mortgage insurer by Arizona regulators last week.

headline: Cigna Targets Seniors With $3.8B HealthSpring Purchase
summary: Cigna agrees to acquire HealthSpring for $3.8 billion, significantly expanding the managed-care company's presence in Medicare-based plans that are expected to fuel industry growth as Baby Boomers age.

headline: Lorillard Net Slips
summary: Lorillard's earnings slipped 2.6% as the cigarette maker struggled with difficult wholesale inventory patterns and weakened margins.

headline: TomTom Rallies as Profit Surges
summary: Dutch navigation-equipment maker TomTom shares rallied 23% as the company posted higher-than-expected profits for the third quarter and said it will cut costs and lay off some workers to halt a slide in sales.

headline: Greek Bank Stocks Plummet
summary: Greek bank stocks plummeted amid fears that a further write-downs in Greece's privately held debt will force billions of euros in fresh losses on the banks.

headline: Nasdaq OMX to Buy Glide Technologies
summary: Nasdaq OMX Group plans to acquire privately held Glide Technologies, a maker of software for managing corporate reputations and communications.

headline: Rice Prices Set to Keep Rising
summary: As flooding in Thailand continues to affect the rice crop and damage existing inventories, global rice prices may move up further—despite cheaper supplies available from sources such as India and Pakistan.

headline: Sterlite Industries Profit Slips 1%
summary: Sterlite Industries, a unit of Vedanta Resources, said its net profit for the fiscal second quarter fell 1%, as raw material and fuel costs shot up while the company also posted a foreign exchange loss of 4.66 billion rupees ($93 million).

headline: Stocks Aim to Beat the Band
summary: U.S. shares pushed above of a two-month trading range Friday. But for gains to continue, investors want to see progress in three areas: Europe's debt and banking crisis, the U.S. economy and corporate earnings.

headline: Invesco Profit Rises
summary: Invesco's third-quarter earnings rose 7.9% as higher investment-management and performance fees boosted revenue, though assets under management declined during a volatile period for markets.

headline: MMTC: India Festival Gold Demand Likely Same as Last Year
summary: India's largest gold importer, state-run MMTC, said its gold sales are likely to be around the same as last year during the peak festival season, as demand has picked up after subdued initial buying.

headline: Biographer: Jobs Downplayed His Cancer
summary: Steve Jobs downplayed the seriousness of his cancer for years even as he received secret treatments, biographer Walter Isaacson told "60 Minutes."

headline: Hong Kong Court Ends Battle for Wang Fortune
summary: The decision by the Court of Final Appeal thwarts any hope for feng-shui adviser Tony Chan to overturn decisions made in the city's lower courts, marking an end to the long battle over the multibillion dollar estate of late businesswoman Nina Wang.

headline: India's Polio Fight
summary: India is moving closer to eradicating polio, having not recorded a case of the debilitating disease in nine months, according to the health ministry. In pictures.

headline: Indian Shares End Up on Global Cues
summary: Indian shares rebounded Monday following two sessions of losses, tracking advances in Asian and European indexes, but gains were limited as investors squared off positions ahead of the central bank's credit policy meeting Tuesday.

headline: Eaton Net Jumps 36%
summary: Eaton's earnings rose 36% as the diversified industrial manufacturer benefited from strong performance in its truck segment.

headline: Reliance Telecom Appeals Against Charges in Telecom Case
summary: Reliance Telecom said it has approached the Delhi High Court to quash charges that the company gained from irregularities during an allocation of mobile-telephone spectrum in 2008.

headline: German Fin Min: EU Financial Transaction Tax Possible
summary: Germany's government considers the introduction of a European Union-wide financial transaction tax to be possible, finance ministry parliamentary state secretary Hartmut Koschyk says.

headline: Infosys to Set Up Office in China's Dalian
summary: Infosys Technologies (China) said it has signed a pact with the government of the Dalian high-technology industrial area to set up a branch company that will focus on software development and outsourcing business in the region.

headline: China Data Boost Asia Shares
summary: Asian markets rose sharply on signs of progress on a plan to contain the euro-zone debt crisis and as data pointed to a rise in Chinese manufacturing. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index jumped 4.1%.

headline: Zambia Mine Workers Reinstated
summary: China-owned mine in Zambia has reinstated at least 1,000 miners who were fired last week for participating in a strike over wages, a sign its starting to bow to government pressure.

headline: Amid Crisis Talks, a Diplomatic Spat
summary: A spat erupted between France and Italy at a euro-zone summit on Sunday, as Italian Premier Silvio Berlusconi seemed unable to force Lorenzo Bini Smaghi to leave his ECB executive-board post.

headline: All Blacks Squeak By
summary: New Zealand ends decades of rugby frustration by hanging on to edge the surprising French team, 8-7, in the World Cup championship match.

headline: Japan Posts Trade Surplus
summary: Japan posted a trade surplus in September, with exports up 2.4%, rolling out better-than-expected results that economists say showed a continued recovery in the supply chain.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: The Wagah border between India and Pakistan, Bhutan's royal couple in New Delhi, a collapsed bridge in West Bengal, and more.

headline: Infiniti Retail Ends Partnership With Woolworths
summary: Tata Group company Infiniti Retail has ended a five-year sourcing partnership with Australian retailer Woolworths Ltd., the Economic Times reported, citing unnamed people close to the development.

headline: George Clooney Leaves Celebrity Comfort Zone
summary: George Clooney, in an interview, talks about his role in "The Descendants," a new movie from Alexander Payne, director of "Sideways." "Every film I do, I'm out of some form of comfort zone," the actor says.

headline: Unfortunately, There Has to Be a Goat
summary: Unless there's an ultra-dramatic finish, someone will have to make the last out of the World Series.

headline: Europe Puts Severe Options on Table
summary: European leaders took their first steps toward a new plan to stem the euro crisis, admitting that their last grand plan, agreed to only three months ago, has failed.

headline: How a Few Bad Apples Ruin Everything
summary: What harm can a few incompetent employees cause? A lot more than you may think.

headline: Tunisia Vote Heeded Across Mideast
summary: Citizens streamed to the polls, lining up for hours to cast ballots in a vote that looked poised to be a groundbreaking step toward democracy in a region struggling to shake off decades of dictatorship.

headline: For Once, Home Field Has Its Advantages for the Jets
summary: The Jets and Rex Ryan talked repeatedly all summer about playing better at home. And thus far, this is one promise the team has delivered on.

headline: Government OfficialsGet Meltdown Pass
summary: "The Shadow of Enron Still Lingers" (Money & Investing, Oct. 17) fails to mention that while the Department of Justice proclaims its diligence in pursuing Wall Street "wrongdoers," there hasn't been one person in government held to account.

headline: Pakistan Releases Indian Helicopter
summary: Pakistan released the crew of a detained Indian helicopter who earlier Sunday had strayed in to Pakistan-controlled airspace in the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir.

headline: Copper's Newest Job: Germ Fighter
summary: A study that showed copper kills bacteria on contact points to an expansion of possible uses for the industrial metal, which is already found in a range of products.  The prospect of hospitals installing copper surfaces have copper producers predicting an increase in demand.

headline: Inspire Trust...and Good  Things Will Follow
summary: Research shows the most-trusted companies have higher revenues, profitability and shareholder returns. Here are five principles leaders can use to inspire trust in themselves and embed trust in the daily cultures of their companies.

headline: Groupon Takes to the Road
summary: Groupon Inc. on Friday let investors know how much of itself it wants to sell, and at what price. This week, it will begin trying to convince big investors to buy in.

headline: Boomerang Employees
summary: Corporate alumni networks—which can make it easier for former employees to become future employees—have made a resurgence as companies struggle to find skilled workers to fill their ranks.

headline: Put on a Happy Face. Seriously.
summary: If your employees start the day in a good mood, it can have a huge impact on the bottom line.

headline: Driving a Volvo? Not for These Swedes
summary: A weak dollar and Sweden's relative economic strength are pumping new life into an old obsession: classic American cars from the 1950s, '60s and '70s.

headline: Against Rules, Tents Arise at Protest
summary: The posted rules in Zuccotti Park are clear: no "camping and/or the erection of tents or other structures." But Occupy Wall Street is beginning to resemble a tent city anyway.

headline: GOP Calendar Gives Romney a Boost
summary: Republican handicappers say Mitt Romney's deep pockets and steadiness in the polls make him the best-positioned to benefit from a nominating calendar that has suddenly been compressed.

headline: Fearing Europe in Japan
summary: Norio Nakajima, head of one of Japan's biggest asset managers, says a gut feeling born of 40 years' experience in the financial markets keeps him awake nights: fear of another flare-up in the European debt crisis.

headline: Sotto Voce Signing
summary: Republicans passed Obama's trade bills, but don't tell anyone.

headline: Shimmer on the Waterfront
summary: The $1 billion-plus East Coast project, a massive, 7-building residential complex in Long Island City that has been two decades in the making, is just past half-done.

headline: Google Links Music Store, Social Networking
summary: Google is building a music-download store that would work closely with its Google+ social network and could launch it within the next two weeks.

headline: Top 'Innovators' Rank Low in R&D Spending
summary: Many companies say innovation is a top priority, but even those who spend the most on research and development can have little to show for it, a new study says.

headline: Paul's Policies Are Foreign to the GOP
summary: Ron Paul's skeptical views on foreign intervention, more than any other, explains his uneasy fit within the Republican Party.

headline: Crunch Time for Franco-German Relations
summary: Unless France and Germany can find a way to resolve their fundamental differences over the next few days, both the euro and the European Union itself could start to unravel—a terrifying prospect.

headline: Thai Floods to Last for Weeks
summary: Attention now is turning to how this major global production hub can avert future crises. The government said floodwaters will pose less of a risk to the capital city of Bangkok by the beginning of November.

headline: Crossing Into U.S. Will Ease in One Spot
summary: Construction will begin Monday on an unmanned border checkpoint at Big Bend, a national park in a remote corner of southwest Texas, even as the federal government has been adding agents to patrol other parts of the U.S.-Mexico boundary.

headline: Panasonic Scraps Solar-Panel Plan
summary: Panasonic is axing a plan to convert a plasma TV panel plant in Japan into one making solar panels, amid cost competition and a global solar-cell supply glut.

headline: Kodak Tensions Rise
summary: Battle lines are hardening between Kodak and its creditors, as worries grow about the struggling photography icon's cash position.

headline: Look Beyond Results When Hiring
summary: When making judgments about whom to hire and promote, it's important to know the situation people worked in, and the methods they used, before judging their performance. Unfortunately, we usually don't. Evidence from several studies suggests that we're biased toward results when making these crucial decisions.

headline: Glimmers in Data Brighten Economic Views
summary: Analysts have been raising their estimates of U.S. economic growth, an about-face from just a month ago, when they were lowering those forecasts and fretting that the country was on the cusp of recession.

headline: Millionaire Watch in Silicon Valley
summary: Eric Trailer is counting down to Nov. 21 like a merchant waiting for Black Friday. That Monday is when social-networking site LinkedIn's employees can begin selling their stock, and Silicon Valley businesses like Mr. Trailer's mortgage firm are gearing up to steer the wealth their way.

headline: A French Country Estate
summary: A Westchester politico owns this stone and clapboard Katonah, N.Y., home with a two-story great room. It has vaulted ceilings, a saltwater pool and outdoor shower.

headline: Flag Creates Flap for Texas License Plates
summary: As a Texas board prepares to vote on whether the Sons of Confederate Veterans can get a license plate featuring the Confederate battle flag, all sides are weighing in.

headline: Protesters Hone the Art of a Movement
summary: Occupy Wall Street may or may not produce an artistic movement, but the arts elements that are emerging suggest that whatever happens there will reflect the non-hierarchical, voice-to-the-majority ethos.

headline: Slowdown in Economy Hits N.J. Industrial Space
summary: The slowdown in the national economy in the third quarter was felt in the market for New Jersey industrial space.

headline: All Blacks End World Cup Drought
summary: With an 8-7 win over France that sent its citizens into an unbridled frenzy, New Zealand claimed the Rugby World Cup, erasing two decades of heartbreak for a nation that lives and breathes rugby.
